contextId.information: In this culture, tearing one's own clothes and putting dirt on one's head was an act of mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: with his clothes torn and with dirt on his head

contextId.information: David and his men tore their clothes as a sign of mourning for the death of King Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: David tore his clothes ... the men with him did the same

contextId.information: In this symbolic act, they poured oil on David's head to show that he was selected to be the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
These were symbolic actions to demonstrate their grief and sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth

contextId.information: These were symbolic actions to show contempt for the men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: cut off their hands and feet and hung them up

contextId.information: This was a symbolic act to honor Ishbosheth. This could be stated explicitly. AT: "they honored Ishbosheth by burying his head in the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they took the head of Ishbosheth and buried it in the grave

contextId.information: To "anoint" is a symbolic act to show that they recognized that God had chosen David as king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: They anointed David king over Israel

contextId.information: She did this to show her respect and submission to the king. AT: "she showed her respect to the king by laying facedown on the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: she lay facedown on the ground

contextId.information: Absalom is showing respect to the king. AT: "bowed low to the ground to honor the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: bowed low to the ground before the king

contextId.information: This implies that the king forgave and restored Absalom. The full meaning of this can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
These men would run in front of the chariot to honor Absalom. AT: "with fifty men to run before him to honor him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: with fifty men to run before him

contextId.information: This action is a friendly greeting. AT: "greet him as a friend by embracing him and kissing him"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: put out his hand and take hold of him and kiss him

contextId.information: This is an act showing shame or repentance. Here the word "earth" means dirt. AT: "He had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head to show that he was very sad" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: with his coat torn and earth on his head

contextId.information: He did this to honor the king. AT: "He bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground to honor the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: He bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground

contextId.information: This is a way to express grief and mourning. AT: "The king showed his grief by covering his face" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
He was showing deep respect and honor to the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: bowed to the king with his face to the ground
